testimony: This is Thursday the 31st of July and it is the Amnesty application of Dumisani Mthembu, number 2618/96.  The members of the Committee are myself Andrew Wilson, Mrs Khampepe and Mr Potgieter.
My name is John Wills, I act for the Applicant.
J Mpshe for the Amnesty Committee.

Mr Chairperson, members of the Committee, I would like to apologize for the delay in the commencement of this hearing.  Basically what occurred was that there was a problem with the location of a second witness which we intended using this morning.  The driver of the vehicle arrived at the agreed meeting place at the correct time and many efforts were exercised to try and locate him.  Unfortunately these were fruitless and time wasting, as a result of which their journey from Sindumbele to here this morning was seriously delayed and they apologise profusely for inconveniencing the Committee in this regard.
Thank you for the explanation.  Carry on.

Mr Chairman, I just want to put it on record that pertaining to the victims here, only one is present with us Mr J W van Schalkwyk.   The other four are not available, thank you Mr Chairperson.   ...(inaudible)
They've all had knowledge - been given notice of the hearing?
My information Mr Chairman, is that they have been informed in terms of the list and their ...(inaudible) thank you Mr Chairman.

Thank you Mr Chairman, prior to me calling the Applicant to testify, I would like to hand in certain documents which I intend using at the hearing.
	The first is a psychiatric report by a Doctor Angelo John Lashish which was done in December 1993.  
	The second document is a sketch plan of the house in question, that is house 1658 Sindumbele and an immediate vicinity house plan of the same house which was compiled as a result of an inspection in loco which I performed.

The report can be Exhibit A.  The larger scale - the area plan - Exhibit B and the Sketch Plan of the house - Exhibit C.
EXHIBITS A , B AND C HANDED IN
Thank you Mr Chairperson.   I call the Applicant.

Mr Mthembu, I'd like you to just realise that whilst you are giving evidence you must talk slowly because as you are giving evidence people are both writing down notes and the evidence you give is being translated, so just speak slowly while you're giving your evidence, thank you.
Mr Mthembu, where do you reside presently?
At the time you made the affidavit in support of your application in December 1996 sorry, September 1996, were you living Sindumbele?
Thank you.  Now you made an affidavit in support of your amnesty application on the 16th September 1996, do you confirm the contents of that affidavit?

You have been charged in the Impangeni Regional Court under Case number RC410 of 1992 in respect of counts relating to two counts of attempted murder, one count involving the illegal possession of a firearm and one count involving the illegal possession of ammunition, do you confirm that?
And do you confirm that you are applying for amnesty in respect of those counts?
That's correct.  I'm here to ask for amnesty in regard to those things.
Now do you admit that on the day in question, i.e. the 2nd of September 1992, you had a Stetchkum/Makerhoff pistol in your possession?
Do you also admit that you had ammunition for this Stetchkum pistol also in your possession?
That's correct, I had ammunition for that firearm.
Now do you admit that on the date in question you were at the house of Mr Vincent Shandu at 1658 Sindumbele?
That's correct, I was at Mr Shandu's place.
What were you doing at Mr Shandu's place?
I used to stay there as a person who was guarding Mr Shandu during the violence.
Who instructed you to guard Mr Shandu?
Instructions were given to me by my commander at that time.
And do you remember the name of your commander?
Can you tell the Committee the name of this commander?
Now what political organisation does Mr Mkunu belong to?
He was an IFP member and also an MK soldier.  ANC and MK.
I think there's been some mistake.  The witness said ANC.

Thank you Committee member.  Now in order for you to perform your duties as a guard, you must have received some form of training, can you tell the Committee if you received such training and tell them where this training occurred.
I was trained in Transkei to protect leaders of my organisation at that time at Sindumbele.
Now what organisation do you belong to?
And when did you first join the ANC?
I became an ANC member in 1989.
Now turning to the firearm, where did you get this firearm from?
I got the firearm from Msizi.
Is this the person you referred to as Mr Msizi Mkunu who you referred to as your commander?
Now why was it necessary to have Cosatu members guarded at that particular time?
The reason was because there were rumours that leaders of the ANC were going to be attacked.  The violence had intensified and many leaders were killed at Mandene at Sindumbele.
Now referring to Mr Shandu, what leader was he?
He was an ANC leader and also a Cosatu leader.
Is it correct that at the time he was in fact the Regional Chairperson of Cosatu in the Northern Natal region?
Now can you remember anybody who was killed in that area around the time that you were guarding Mr Shandu?
The person who got killed was Ken Shandu.
He was attacked and hit by a petrol bomb and they also shot him.
And was this Ken Shandu actually the brother of Vincent Shandu?

Now I'm going to turn now to the incident in question, that is the events that occurred in the early hours of the morning of the 2nd of September 1992.  You said you were in Mr Shandu's house at that stage, is that correct?
Yes, I was in Mr Shandu's house at that time.
Can you tell the Committee what, how you were woken up and what happened immediately thereafter.

I woke up when I heard gunshots in the house - we were surprised - I woke up and entered the passage of the house and we were being shot at and I fired shots back to the people who were shooting at us.  After that Mr Shandu called out asking what's happening, who are shooting at us?  They shouted back saying we are the police.
Okay, when you - you said you were woken up by shots being fired, at that stage did you know who the people were outside who were shooting at you?
In my mind I thought those were the people who attacked our place,  I didn't think it would be police who were shooting at us.
Then what did you do?  You said you fired some shots, can you remember how many shots you fired?
If I remember well I shot three times.
And did you shoot with the weapon that you referred to earlier, i.e. the Stetchkum pistol?
Yes, I used it - the one that I referred to before.
Now did you aim this at any particular person, when you were shooting were you aiming at any particular person?
I didn't aim at a particular person, I just shot at the direction from where the shots were coming from.
Can you, - you've said that Mr Shandu shouted outside and then the police indicated it was the police, can you tell the Committee what happened thereafter?

After Shandu shouted asking who they were, the police replied saying, we are the police.  After that the police said Shandu should open the door.  Shandu asked, aren't you going to shoot us and they said no we won't and they insisted that he open the door.
Shandu opened the door and after opening the door they told him to raise his hands and put them on top of his head, both of them and get out of the house.

They searched him and also took him outside and they instructed him to lie down on the ground on his stomach and they were pointing a firearm behind, from behind while he was lying on the ground.  After that Vusi came, he's my brother who - he were with us.  They also searched him and they also instructed him to lie on the floor on his stomach, they also pointed a firearm behind him while lying on the ground.
	The third one was myself.  They also searched me and they told me to go and lie on the floor on my stomach.  After that they woke me up, they picked me up, grabbed me and picked me up and put - and drove me back - pushed me back into the house.  There were three policemen.  While, after entering the house they said I must point a firearm.  I entered the kitchen with them and I pointed the firearm next to a kitchen scheme.
Did they say, point a firearm or point out a firearm?
May you please repeat your question?

Did they say, point a firearm or did they say he must point out a firearm?  Perhaps I should explain that translated into English in that way - point a firearm usually means point a firearm at a person.  If they say point out a firearm, it means show them where it is.

They said I must point out a firearm.  I pointed out the firearm and they said - they pushed me towards the gun and said I must pick it up.  They were pointing guns at me standing by the kitchen door and they were saying I must pick it up and if I don't pick it up, they're going to shoot me.  While they were pointing the firearms at me saying that I should pick up the firearm and if I don't they going to shoot me, I kicked it because I thought they were going to shoot me.  	After that I didn't see what happened however, even if I have told them that they mustn't shoot me, I do know what happened.  I remember the last time I remembered was when I said,  pleading with them that they mustn't shoot me.  I don't remember what happened after I took the firearm because they were pointing guns at me and saying that I shot their friend.  One of them took out a gun and pointed it at me and said I shot his friend.  After that I woke up at Wentworth, I regained my consciousness at Wentworth Hospital.
Mr Mthembu I can see that you have a wound on the left side of your forehead, it's very apparent.  Is that the wound that you sustained on the day in question?
Yes, that's where they shot me.
Now how long did you spend in hospital?
I don't remember well, I would say it was about four weeks or five.
Can you tell the Committee what occurred after you were released from hospital?

They took me from Wentworth to Stanga Hospital where I stayed for one week.  Thereafter they took me and charged me.  That's where I heard that at the time when we were attacked and I shot in retaliation, one police was injured.
Sorry, did you say that was the first time that you realised that somebody was injured, possible by yourself?
That was the first day coming from hospital that I discovered that I shot someone during the day when we were fighting or shooting at each other.
Do you remember that at about that time that you made a statement to the police in regard to the incident?  That was after you had come out of hospital.
I remember the statement that I gave to the police.

In fact that was made on the 30th of September 1992, is that correct?  Committee members I'm referring to the exhibit that commences at page 48 of the bundle and continues until page 55.   Did you tell the truth in this statement?
I will say I didn't tell the truth in that statement, I was afraid.  Secondly, I wasn't well because I was just out from hospital.

Members of the Committee, in this regard I refer to Exhibit A as it's relevant at this stage and I specifically refer to page 4.  It's the 4th page but actually listed page 3 of Doctor Lashishe's report and particularly the paragraph entitled Opinion and I specifically refer to the final sentence of the psychiatric report and I quote
"It is questionable whether on 30th of September 1992 he was competent and/or able to appreciate the legal implications of making a statement to the police".
	Obviously the reasons for that opinion are more fully set out in the body of the report.
	Mr Mthembu you referred to somebody earlier in your evidence as Vusi, that being Israel Vusimusi Mtule, is that correct, the person you travelled with today?
And Vusi was in the house with you that night?
Yes, he was in the house.

Now just for clarity, you indicated to the Committee when you were in the kitchen with the police and they were pointing firearms at you and ordering you to pick up the firearm, did you actually touch the firearm with your hands?
I didn't pick it up with my hands, I was afraid that they were going to shoot me.
I said when they insisted that I should pick it up, I didn't pick it up.   I ended up kicking it up, kicking it with my foot towards their direction.

Thank you.  Sorry, there's one final incident.  I have some photographs here and I must apologise to the members of the Committee, I have only got one set of these photographs but if I can just show you these photographs.  I just want you to peruse those photographs and tell me if they are photographs taken of the house and the interior of the house at 1658 Sindumbele, i.e. Mr Shandu's house.  Just look at the photographs please.  Are those photographs of both the exterior and the interior, certain interior parts of Mr Shandu's house?
	Just place on record that I've shown about thirteen photographs there, busy going through each of them.
	Are you in a position to tell us?  Can you tell the Committee whether or not those are photographs taken from Shandu's house.
These pictures they show the house of Mr Shandu after the incidents, all of them.
Yes sorry, I apologise Mr Chairperson.
There are sixteen photographs in the ...(inaudible)
The speaker's mike is not on.

There are sixteen photographs in the bundle.  I think they can be referred to as Exhibit D.  Are you going to refer to any of them individually?
EXHIBIT D HANDED IN
No, I'm not going to refer to, it's just to give the Committee an idea of the ...(intervention)

Well before then, can I refer to six of the photographs that seem to show pock marking on the walls.  Sorry, the seventh, external six so pock markings to the internal walls.  Were these marks of bullets that were there after this, the night in question?
That's correct, that happened on that particular day.

And are there also some bullet marks on the outside of the house, in particular one of both sides of the window that appears to have been shattered, of the front window of the house where you can see the number 1658?  Do you agree there were bullet marks on the outside of the house as well and the window was shattered?  You wouldn't know would you, you can't say what it looked like after the house, shooting because you were taken away to the hospital.

Mr Chairperson, I just want to basically him to identify the home at this stage.  My next witness will identify the ...(intervention)  Sorry, could the Committee just bear with me, I just want to consult with the evidence leader very briefly.
	Just for reference Mr Chairperson, members of the Committee, my learned friend is in agreement that I can place this on record.  I personally did an inspection in loco at the home shortly after the incident and counted fourteen bullet holes through the kitchen door, nine through the lounge door.  There were twenty seven big bullet holes on the interior lounge wall.  I have a list of this which I will hand in.  There were fifty what looked like bullet holes on the, small bullet holes on the interior lounge wall.  There were eight big potholes in the interior of the kitchen wall, there were fifty plus bullet holes in the interior kitchen walls, there were three bullet holes into the sink, there were four through the kitchen table.  In the main bedroom there were eight big bullet holes and thirty five small bullet holes and on the outside there were at least twelve bullet holes, indicting two hundred and twenty marks.  Now just sorry, ...(intervention)

Exhibit E.
EXHIBIT E HANDED IN

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
	Mr Mthembu, you mentioned this firing, can you give an estimate of the length of the firing or if there was a lot or a little bit of firing immediately after you woke up and before you yourself were shot?
The gunshots we heard in the beginning when they started to shoot at and also when I shot back at them, the gunshots continued until the owner of the house started calling out, Mr Shandu.

Thank you.  There's no further questions for this witness, thank you Mr Chairperson, members of the Committee.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR WILLS

Sorry, if I could just intervene once more here, it's been pointed out to me that I've made a glaring mistake and that refers to the injury on the Applicant's head.  I indicated that it was on the left side of his head, it's actually on the right hand side of his head, thank you.
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Mthembu why were you chosen to be the bodyguard of Mr Shandu?

Maybe it's the way we were working together with Mr Msizi as we have ...(inaudible) complained that people were getting killed, the leaders were getting killed.  That might have been the reason.  I was the one who always insisted to Msizi that he must come and help us at  Mandene.
When you started shooting the two, the three bullets, the three shots outside, whom did you think you were shooting at?
I was shooting at a person who was direct to the window was shooting into the house.  I had to shoot through the window because I saw some bullets get into the house through the window.
What did you suspect the person you were shooting at outside to be?
I thought they were the attackers.  The attackers - we have heard that they might come or they have attacked, or they will come to attack Mr Shandu on those particular days.

What attackers you heard would come or come to attack Mr Shandu, what attackers were those?  Did you think of thugs that were going to attack Mr Shandu, did you think of people from some place coming to attack Mr Shandu?
Those were people who used to attack ANC members in Mandene.  They were IFP members.  We were still fighting when it comes to followers and also just as organisations.
Now referring to the statement you made to the police when you were led by my learned friend, you said that what you said to the police is not true because you were afraid, do you remember that?
Were you also afraid to disclose even names to the police?
I was afraid to mention names but I didn't have the names of the attackers which I could have disclosed to the police.
Were you afraid even to mention names of people in your own organisation?
Yes, I was afraid to mention names of my fellow comrades and even those who were working underground.

It was because police intimidated me because there was the people who came to fetch me and the statement that I have to make we were, I made the statement while in the car from hospital to the police station and thereafter they took me to the cells.
Didn't you mention a name - didn't you say to the police that you picked up the firearm at a roadblock?

I did say that because I was afraid that they were going to harass me or torture me because in most of the cases when they investigating cases, they were intimidating people and in those days when they said they were going to shoot you, they were really going to shoot you.

Now in your affidavit - I refer members of the Committee to page 5 of the bundle - in your affidavit, the last paragraph thereof, you state that during 1992 there was a considerable amount of violence in the Northern Natal area and many ANC and Cosatu leaders and officials were killed.
Can you tell us the figure or the number of Cosatu officials that were killed in that area?

On that day there were no other people who were attacked.  This is what I heard when I came out of hospital but before I went to Shandu's place people who had been killed, there were over five of leaders, the leaders were over five.  That is the reason why I was asked to go to Mandene.
Now over to page 7 of your affidavit still ...(intervention)
Mr Mpshe, can I will your permission just interpose for consistence?  Mr Mthembu, can you name these five leaders who had been killed?
The one that I remember is Ken Shandu but that was the last person to be killed, he was a prominent person and that's why I had to be asked to go to Mandene.
And when was Ken Shandu killed, can you remember?  The month not the date because I'm sure it won't be possible for you to remember the date.
And the others?  Any of the others that you can remember out of the five?
Others were killed before Ken was killed.
The names thereof, are you able to give us their names?
I don't remember their names because they were not people whom I knew very well.
Thank you Ma'am.  The last one who was killed that you mentioned, Ken Shandu, where was he killed?
He had a homestead of Mr Shandu just outside the township, the township of Sindumbele.
By Shandu are you referring to Vincent Shandu the one you were his bodyguard?
Are you saying Kenny Shandu?  Kenny Shandu was killed just outside the house of Vincent Shandu?
Are you putting that to him?
I'm trying to get clarity on there.
Well what he said he was killed at Sindumbele, he had a homestead just outside the township.  I don't recollect him having mentioned just outside the house of the other person.
Mr Chairman, I heard them interpret to me, the homestead of Shandu.  Did you say he was killed outside the house of Shandu?
They are nervous in the township.  His home is just outside the township but near, Shandu's house is in the township.
Was this Shandu who was killed, killed in his own house?
That's correct, he was killed in his home.

Referring to page 7 of your affidavit once more, the last paragraph thereof which I will quote for your convenience
"Whilst I admit I may have injured someone - now here comes the important part - I only shot in defence of me and the other occupants of the house".
That was my aim, to protect myself and the people who were inside the house.
Was this  your only aim, is it the only reason why you shot, to protect these people and nothing else?
The reason, it was because people were shooting into the house where I was in and I had to shoot back to protect people who were with me in the house at that time.
Will I be correct if I say that you would have shot at anybody who was shooting at the house,  you didn't have any particular person or persons in mind, you were to shoot against or at?
I didn't intend to shoot any particular person, I was shooting because I heard the gunshots from outside therefore to protect those who were inside the house, I had to shoot.
Put this way, the defence you're talking about in your affidavit, were you defend the occupants of the house against anything or something in particular?
I was protecting them because they were attacked before therefore I had to protect them and I had to protect them even at the time when they were getting attacked.
You'll have to forgive me but I've got to put it on.  Did you have a particular target in your defence?
It was at night therefore I couldn't see people who were outside.  I was shooting at the direction where I suspected that the bullets were coming from.

Thank you Mr Chairman, no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MPSHE

I have certain questions which I would rather not ask and if you can supply the information we'd perhaps save a lot of time.  Have you got a copy of the charge of indictment that is being brought against him?

In fact I've been requesting that for some time from the Prosecutors at the Regional Court.  The charge sheet has not been drawn up.  It is simply, I'm told that the charges are in respect of attempted murder.  I have, I think in my files I have an updated charge sheet, it has subsequently been changed but if you can bear with me I'll see if I can assist.
Well can I tell you what the difficulty that has come to my mind that I have been reading the papers and I have of these weapons before and it is described as a machine pistol.

Now in terms of our Firearm Act, machine weapons are classified differently from ordinary firearms and in the event of him applying for amnesty he would not be - if it was, if this weapon is, does fall into the category of automatic weapons, it would be a separate offence, a different offence from the ordinary offence of unlawful possession of a firearm and accordingly ...(intervention)

I think we ought to have more precise details as to precisely what he's applying for amnesty for.  That is to ascertain the nature of the charge.  I don't want to start asking him about the automatic weapon and the effect of it.  There is a very detailed description of the weapon in the papers.
Could you do that, find that out?

Yes, thank you.  Mr Chairperson, I can possibly answer that in that there is obviously by the evidence that's been supplied, the evidence by the docket, the evidence of the ballistics specialist, there's obviously the intention to charge and in respect of the more serious offence of a machine pistol.  I apologise for not actually making that clear in the application but clearly that is what is intended.  He is wanting amnesty in respect of the possession of the particular firearm which is classified as a machine firearm and if one looks at the ballistics report, my recollection is, is that it does work on automatic fire which certainly classifies it as a machine pistol.
It seems you can't fire a single shot, you can fire automatic or semi-automatic.
Mr Mpshe, I take it you have no objection to us giving proper details of what the firearm's ...(intervention)
I've no objections Mr Chairman, I take the point.

I have no re-examination, thank you Mr Chairperson.

I have simply one more witness in this matter and I - at the Committee's convenience as regards the length of the adjournment, I'm prepared to go ahead at any stage.
Well if we adjourn till 2, we'll finish easily by 4, won't we Mr Mpshe?

Mr Chairperson, may I request an indulgent.  There is just one question that I omitted to ask the Applicant.  It will take a minute. My learned friend has no objections, can I be permitted to do so?
Mr Mthembu, I want you to cast  your mind back from when you were outside the house and the police took you back into the kitchen of the house.
He took me back into the kitchen.
Okay, can you tell me if you remember whether or not there were any lights on inside the house at that stage?
The place which we entered which had light was the lounge area.  In the kitchen the police light, light on the light - I don't know what kind of light.
Are you saying that as you went into the kitchen the police switched the kitchen light on?
The kitchen light was off.  When we entered the kitchen, the police switched the lights on.

Thank you Mr Chairperson, members of the Committee, I call Mr Vusimusi Israel Mtule as the second witness for the Applicant.
Mr Mtule, you're a member of the ANC?
That's correct, I'm an ANC member.
You're also an active unionist in that you are employed by NUMSA in the Esetebe area as an organiser, is that correct?
Yes, I'm being employed by the National Union of Metal Workers of South Africa as the Branch Organiser.
How long have  you acted as a union official, or been employed as a union official?
I was employed as the union official since 1989.
Now can you just give the Committee some details of your ANC membership, when did you first become a member of the ANC?
I must say since I was born and bred but I started to become a proactive ANC member as from 1984 and thereafter I was involved in the Trade Union activities in 1989.

Now just around the time of the incident, the incident in respect of which Mr Mthembu is applying for amnesty, that is in September 1992, prior to that are you able to say whether or not you knew of Cosatu officials or ANC members having violent attacks directed toward them?

Yes indeed, I am aware of too many incidents where the ANC and Cosatu members were being attacked and in some cases their houses were burnt down and lives were also lost in the process of which one of the victims was Ken Shandu.
Now my understanding is that this violence was not only restricted to the area within which you operated but also was extended to places like Isekaweni, is that correct?
Yes indeed, incidents of that sort did take place around Isekaweni, Mtambeni and other surroundings areas of Mandene.
Now I want you to focus on the role that you were playing in regard to your ANC portfolio at the time around the attack, what position did you in fact hold?
In fact I must say I was a political commissar in the ANC / MK underground structure.
Now for how long or when did you first hold that position and for how long did you hold that position?
I had that position from having obtained the military training in 1985.
And in respect of which area were you deployed?
I was deployed to be rendering the organising mission of the ANC around the North Coast of which Mandene was one of the areas that I was responsible for.
Now you've heard the Applicant in his evidence make reference to a person by the name of Msizi Mkunu, do you know that person?

Yes, I know Msizi Mkunu as a Commissar in the military but he was later a commander of Umkhonto in Northern Natal by the time when the incident took place so he was a commander in chief in the office of ...(inaudible) security of the ANC.
Now do I understand your evidence that he was in fact the overall commander for the Northern Natal region of the ANC at that stage?
Now do you bear any knowledge of the evidence that the Applicant gave in respect of the instructions he received from Mr Mkunu to guard the house of Mr Shandu and in fact Mr Shandu's existence?
Yes indeed, I was aware as I used to coordinate the activities of the MK in the area, so I am aware of the instructions that were given to Dumisani by Msinzi being the commander in chief.
Now Mr Mthembu's also testified to the effect that he was supplied a Stetchkum machine pistol from Mr Mkunu, can you testify to the Commission whether or not this is in fact the truth?
This is the truth and nothing, it is the truth, he was given the Stetchkum as an instrument to use and safeguard the life of Mr Shandu who was in the brink of being attacked.
Now turning to the actual event itself, that is the events of the morning of the 2nd of September 1992, Mr Mthembu has testified that you were in the house and we know that is in fact correct.
Yes indeed, I was in the house.
Now can you describe briefly what occurred from, why you woke up and thereafter.

I was fast asleep and I hear the storm of gunshots firing into the house of the room in which we were and the glasses that came up around my face made me to actually wake up apart from the noise of the gunshot that I heard when I woke up.

Now in bundle of documents that I have been supplied with by the Truth Commission, there are statements from the police members who conducted the raid and they are emphatic to the effect that they knocked on the door and notified that they were the police prior to any shots being fired, can you comment on that?

I vehemently oppose that statement made by the police as being the total blue lie.  The only time and the only moment when I ever heard a gunshot that came through and the glasses that came through the window and thereafter the noise of a man who was saying Willem skiet, Willem skiet (Willem shoot, Willem shoot) -that was a command from outside.

Now I showed Mr Mthembu some photographs which he identified as being taken of Mr Shandu's house.  I would like you to have a look at these photographs.  You will notice that there are, they are photographs which depict certain bullet holes in both the interior and exterior walls of the house.  Are you able to tell this Committee whether those bullet holes were there before the attack?

I must testify that these bullet holes were not in the walls before the attack, they only happened to be the holes in the wall after the incident, in other words they are a direct result of an attack by the police.

Now you've heard Mr Mthembu give evidence to the effect that after the shooting ceased, the occupants of the house were essentially flushed out and ordered to come out with their hands up, one by one.
Yes indeed, that happened after Vincent Shandu has asked who the attackers were.
At the time the bullets were going off, did you know who the people were outside who were shooting?

No, we didn't know who the people outside were except that I could only, as a person who also understands and speak fluent Afrikaans, I could only hear the voice of a man saying skiet (shoot) and it may be upon that assumption that one would assume that it's a certain koevoet operation.  That's what comes into my mind I must say.
Okay now you went, you together with others were essentially under the arrest of the police on the outside of the house, is that correct?
Can you tell me what happened to you when you walked outside, how were you asked to position yourself?

In the first place I must say I was half dressed having only the ...(inaudible) with me and we were commanded to come out.  The man whom I identified later as Mr Botha said, come out - put your hands in the air otherwise I shoot, otherwise I shoot, come out,  come out, come out.  Then we had to come out having our sort of arms hanging over like this, not like this otherwise he was not going to see them.
	You could firstly come out with your hands and then he could - he probably grabbed me so to say right up here and he brought me down just to the floor and I had to lie down.
